course.subject: BIOMG
course.course_title: Principles of Cell and Developmental Biology

notes.note: Biological science majors must take this course for a letter grade.
Not open to students majoring in biological sciences; may not be used to fulfill requirements for biological sciences major. Highly recommended: problem-solving sessions.

Recommended prerequisite: BIOG 1500. Lab assignment made first day of class. Labs are held Tues, Wed, Thurs, and Fri 2:30-4:30pm. Problem solving sessions are strongly recommended: Tues or Wed 8:30-10am. (3rd session by arrangement with instructor). Not open to freshmen fall semester. View Prelim Schedule: http://registrar.sas.cornell.edu/Sched/exams.html

Prerequisite: one majors-level biology course and one year general chemistry; and CHEM 1570, or 3570-3580, or equivalents; or permission of instructor. CHEM 3580 may be co-registered. May not be taken for credit after BIOMG 3310, 3320, 3330, or 3350. Co-registration in BIOMG 3340 is encouraged. Biological sciences majors must take course for a letter grade. Organizational meeting: Monday, Jan. 23rd, 4:30 P.M., BKL 200. Attendance is required. Meets in 219 Stimson.

Prerequisite: previous enrollment in course to be taught or equivalent. Note: Arts students may not count this course toward graduation but may, upon petition (one time only) to their class dean, carry fewer than 12 other credits and remain in good standing. This would affect Dean's List eligibility but not eligibility for graduating with distinction.

course.subject: BIOMG
course.course_title: Current Topics in Genetics and Development

notes.note: Organization Meeting TBA. This course will present a variety of career options for those students earning doctoral degrees in the life sciences,including non-traditional career options. Invited speakers from a broad spectrum of professions will provide first hand accounts of their backgrounds, training and career paths, professional responsibilities, and perspectives on their chosen careers. Students in the course will participate by asking questions during the meeting sessions and by hosting the speakers for meals and/or social hours. The course will likely have six to eight sessions, one per week, each with one to three speakers. The course will meet once during the first two weeks of classes to review the schedule of meeting times for the rest of the semester and to select the student hosts. At the end of the course, students will be asked to write a brief summary of their skills, interests, and career goals.

course.subject: BIOMG
course.course_title: Current Topics in Genetics and Development

notes.note: Organization Meeting TBA. First meeting will be the week of January 30, 2012. Brief description: This course will be on Grant Proposal Writing in a format designed to assist 2nd year Genetics and Development students with their A exam proposals.

course.subject: BIOMG
course.course_title: Research Seminar in Genetics and Development

notes.note: Enrollment limited to and required for: second-year and beyond graduate students in genetics and development.
Enrollment limited to: graduate students in Genetics and Development.

Organization meeting Feb 27 with class meetings on Mondays-April 2, April 9, April 16 and April 23rd. This minicourse is an introduction or review for students interested in quantitative treatments of dynamical biological interactions including diffusion, ligand binding, enzyme kinetics, and receptor regulation of cellular activities. We will develop basic equilibrium and kinetic equations and consider these in terms of appropriate application to and evaluation of data. We will consider examples in the literature. The specific meeting times for the course will be decided at the organizational meeting. Please contact Professor Baird (bab13) if you have questions.

Organization meeting Feb 27 with class meeting times in March. This minicourse is an introduction or review for students interested in quantitative treatments of dynamical biological interactions including diffusion, ligand binding, enzyme kinetics, and receptor regulation of cellular activities. We will develop basic equilibrium and kinetic equations and consider these in terms of appropriate application to and evaluation of data. We will consider examples in the literature. The specific meeting times for the course will be decided at the organizational meeting. Please contact Professor Baird (bab13) if you have questions.
Enrollment limited to: graduate students majoring in field of biochemistry, molecular and cell Biology.
Enrollment limited to and required for: first-year graduate students in field of biochemistry, molecular and cell biology.
Enrollment limited to and required for: second-, third-, and fourth-year graduate students majoring in field of biochemistry, molecular and cell biology.

course.subject: BIOMG
course.course_title: Quantitative Biology for Molecular Biology and Genetics

notes.note: Enrollment limited to: first-year Ph.D. students in the graduate fields of biochemistry, molecular and cell biology, or genetics and development. For all other students, permission of instructor is required.

Enrollment limited to: second-year graduate students majoring in field of biochemistry, molecular and cell biology. All other students, permission of instructor is required. Organizational Meeting: Jan 23; 5 PM; Room 180 Biotech Building.
